stem: The patient is exhibiting signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Review the nursing note below and highlight all findings that support this diagnosis. Each highlighted finding is worth one point.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Walker, 68-year-old male, admitted 02:00 today for acute ischemic stroke, right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. NIHSS score upon admission was 18. B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Last dose of IV Alteplase completed at 03:30. A: At 07:00, patient's GCS has decreased from 14 to 11. Pupils are now unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive, left pupil 3mm and reactive to light. Patient is now requiring increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%. Noted new onset of left-sided weakness. BP trending upward. R: Recommend immediate neurological assessment and CT scan of the head without contrast to evaluate for increased ICP and possible hemorrhagic conversion. Consider administering mannitol per protocol. Notify neurosurgery for emergent consultation if ICP continues to rise.

tabs.title: Nursing Note
tabs.content: 07:00: Patient assessed. Level of consciousness decreased; GCS now 11 (Eyes 2, Verbal 4, Motor 5) compared to 14 on admission. Pupils unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive to light, left pupil 3mm and reactive. New onset of left-sided weakness noted (1/5 motor strength). Patient reports headache. Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%. BP elevated to 200/110. No seizure activity observed. Acetaminophen administered for headache. Neurologist notified.

rationale.correct: The highlighted findings (Level of consciousness decreased; GCS now 11 (Eyes 2, Verbal 4, Motor 5), Pupils unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive to light, Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%, BP elevated to 200/110, New onset of left-sided weakness noted (1/5 motor strength)) directly indicate increased ICP. A decreasing GCS indicates worsening neurological function. Unequal pupils, particularly a dilated and sluggish pupil, suggests pressure on the oculomotor nerve. The need for increased oxygen is due to possible respiratory compromise secondary to brainstem compression. Elevated blood pressure is the body's attempt to maintain cerebral perfusion (Cushing's Triad). New onset of weakness indicates increased pressure on motor pathways.
rationale.incorrect: Acetaminophen administration, although relevant to patient care, does not directly support increased ICP. While headache is a symptom of increased ICP, it is a subjective complaint and not an objective finding. Neurologist notification is an appropriate action but not a direct assessment finding. The patient's report of a headache may be related to increased ICP, but it is not as direct and objective as the other findings.
clinicalPearls: Cushing's Triad (bradycardia, irregular respirations, and widened pulse pressure) is a late sign of increased ICP.
Early recognition of increased ICP is crucial to prevent irreversible brain damage.
Maintain the head of the bed at 30 degrees to promote venous drainage and reduce ICP.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the stroke diagnosis instead of recognizing the signs and symptoms of increased ICP, a complication of the stroke.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully analyze each finding and consider its relationship to increased ICP pathophysiology. Remember the compensatory mechanisms and the signs of decompensation.
